statement.tex:
%text Examine the continuity of $f(x)$ where $f(x)$ is defined as
% \qquad f(x) = \begin{cases} \sin x - \cos x, x\neq 0 \\ -1, x = 0 \end{cases}

options.tex: %text \textcolor{blue}{\text{To Prove}} $f(x)$ is continuous for all $x$ -- and not just $x=0$ or some other $x$ %

reason.tex:
%text The question clearly asks us to \underline\text{examine the continuity} of $f(x)$
Which means, you must also think about whether $f(x)$ is continuous at $x=\pi$ or $x=-10,000$ %

%text If two functions $A(x)$ and $B(x)$ are \underline\text{independently} continuous in some domain, then so are $A(x) + B(x)$ and $A(x) - B(x)$.
And as $\sin x$ and $\cos x$ are both \underline\text{continuous for every $x\neq 0$}, therefore so is $f(x) = \sin x - \cos x$.
%

options.tex:
\[ \lim_{x\to 0}f(x) \neq f(0) \] %text
Hence, $f(x)$ is continuous only for $x\neq 0$ %
